text: a man's voice, small, filtered by great distance:
Dad?... Dad?
I can hardly hear you.
Start very close on a phone and Hank's ear.
(phone filter) I said your son has gone AWOL.

(confused) My son is in Iraq. Widen to see HANK DEERFIELD cradling the phone, sitting o the edge of his bed. You don't have to ask if Hank has se war, he speaks with the confidence of someone who has bee to hell and mapped the terrain. He keeps himself in shape and is not a man who is often caught off guard, which mak his confusion that much more troubling.
Your son was in Iraq, sir. His unit arrived stateside four days ago.
Soldier, if my son was back I would sure as hell know about it. JOAN DEERFIELD, Hank's wife, enters to check what's going on. Joan's a good looking woman, younger than Hank.
Sir, Sergeant Carnelli asked me to tell you your son has until Sunday to get back to the base, or he'll be listed as absent. I'm sorry, I have another call. CLICK. Hank hangs up.
Who was that? (CONTINUED)
Some horse's ass. Did Mike email you?
Why on earth would he do that? He knows I can't read the darn things.
(exiting) You really should have someone show you sometime.
(calling after him) Sarcasm is not your most endearing quality, Hank.

Hank's desk sits in the corner of an unfinished attic roo Hank checks his answering machine, no messages. He taps t older model laptop computer on his desk; the black screen disappears, revealing his email program: one message -- someone looking for a missing weigh bill. Hank picks up t phone and presses an autodial number.
This is Mike, leave a message and if I ever get a signal I'll call you back. Beep.
Hey, Mike, it's your old man. Heard you're back. Give me a ring when you get a chance. Hank hangs up, considers.

Theirs is a modest two bedroom home lying a front-yard's distance off the highway. An ancient but well maintained dump truck sits at the back of a long gravel drive, front end jacked up. The truck door reads Deerfield Hauling. Hank slides out from under the truck with a tie rod and w in his hand. He drops the rod into the box of his 1989 Fo F150 pickup, puts his wrench in the tool chest and pulls his coveralls. (CONTINUED)
As the pickup pulls out of the drive we widen to see the rows of identical houses lining the highway, most of them proudly displaying American flags. Welcome to the town of Munroe, Tennessee.
Hank waits, the busted tie rod on the counter. A TV in th corner plays a press conference about the state of the wa STU, the 60ish salesman, returns with a new rod.
There you go.
You're sure this one will fit.

You gotta trust somebody sometime, Hank. (re: TV) Bet Mike will have some stories to tell, won't he? Course now they can see at night and shoot through concrete walls, almost makes you sorry for the ragheads. Big difference from our day.
What day was that?
...What do you mean?
Stu, unless I'm mistaken, the only action you saw was Kent State. Shot a school boy, didn't you?
...That was a riot, and I didn't kill anybody.
Yeah. That's what I heard. Hank takes the tie rod and leaves.
Hank steps out of the PARTS STORE and gets into his picku He slows as he passes the local high school, noticing... (CONTINUED)
Kids entering don't notice the American flag flying upsid down.
Hank enters to be greeted by LENORE, the cheerful receptionist. The flag is clearly visible from the window
Hi.
Why hello there.
I'm Hank Deerfield.

Mike's dad, I know that. You know we are all just so proud of Mike and our other boys serving their country...and girls...did you know Cheri Michaels is flying a helicopter? Flunked Drivers Ed and they let her fly a whirlybird.
Miss...
Lenore.
Lenore. Have you looked out your window this morning?
This window right here?
This window right here. Do you see anything odd? The flag?... (nothing) See how it's flying upside down?
Oh, gosh, I didn't notice that. Oh dear. Well don't you worry, I will have that put right first thing in the morning. (CONTINUED)
It is the morning.
We just get so busy here.
Lenore, do you happen to know what it means, a flag flying upside down?
That someone's died?
No--
--See, I always get that wrong.
--That's flying at half mast.
Could mean that the person putting it up wasn't paying a lot of attention. She laughs at her own joke, as she often does.
Yeah, it could. But it doesn't. Who raises the flag every morning, the principal?
Oh, good gosh no, he comes running in about one minute before nine; no it's Juan, our janitor.
(this is getting worse by the second) The janitor raises the flag. who takes it down at night?
Juan.
Right. So, why don't we ask Juan to fix it right now? (CONTINUED)
Oh, I couldn't do that. He has so much to do; you know they laid off all the other janitorial staff, with cutbacks and such, he can hardly keep up as it is.
Fine. Then I'll do it.
Oh, I'm afraid I can't let you handle school property; it's an insurance issue.
A flag is not school property. All flags are property of the US government, who loan them to us under the promise that we treat them with respect.
No, I'm pretty sure we bought that one. I know because I had to order it when we threw the old one in the trash.
In the trash. Listen, before I get myself in a lot trouble, why don't you just tell me where to find Juan?
Flooded, Hank stands in an inch of brown water. JUAN drop his pipe wrench back into his toolkit on the sink. Juan h a Mayan face and speaks with the accent of an immigrant.
Now? Hank slips him a ten dollar bill.
I'd really appreciate it. Juan shrugs and heads out, wiping his hands. Hank takes a long look at the mess before exiting.
Juan reattaches the flag. Hank snags the tip just before hits the grass.
You don't let it touch the ground.
Okay.
Where are you from?
El Salvador.
What's your flag look like?
A flag.
You know what it means when a flag is hung upside down? (he doesn't) It's an international distress signal.
No shit.
No shit. It means we are in a whole lot of trouble, so come save our ass, cause we haven't got a prayer in hell of saving ourselves.
It says a lot.
Yes, it does. So, you know how to do it now?
Oh, yes.
Good. Juan looks up at the flag flying. Hank walks to his truck
Joan watches from the kitchen window. Out in the drive, Hank lies under his dump truck, smacking the rod with a mallet. He curses it and rises.
(passing the kitchen) Anyone call?
No. Joan watches him tread upstairs.
The phone rings in Hank's ear, until:
Fort Rudd, how may I direct your call?
First Sgt. Arnold Bickman, Criminal Investigations Division.
...I'm sorry, sir, I have no one by that name on base.
Thank you. Hank hangs up, swivels in his chair and sees Joan standin in the open doorway.
You going to tell me?

Hank opens his top drawer, removes three neatly folded pa of underwear, socks, three white undershirts. He tucks th into a small zip bag and opens his second drawer, removes three starched white cotton shirts and a shoe shine kit.
I want to go with you. (CONTINUED)
If he's holed up somewhere celebrating, the last thing he needs is his mother walking in on him. I'll call you when I get there tomorrow night.
It's a two day drive.
For some people. He kisses her on the forehead, puts his laptop under his and exits.

Copies of Soldier of Fortune share the shelves with sport memorabilia and snapshots of Mike and his buddies in Bosn (circa 2001) and Iraq (2003). Hank fingers an autographed football, puts it back and slips a photo of Mike in his d uniform out of the frame. He pockets it and heads out, flicking off the light.
The pickup speeds along, passing a car or two.
Hank does what he does best, drive. An oncoming big rig blinds him with its high beams. Hank squints.
Dad? Dad?
Dad!
Hank WAKES with a start. He hears tapping. Hank looks to his driver's side window and is surprised to see...
standing at the open window, chewing gum. Tattoos, scarre face, someone you would cross the street to avoid. Hank tries not to react. (CONTINUED)
How ya doin'?
Good. You?
Very good. You got a light? Hank pushes in his cigarette lighter and they wait. Tense It pops out. Hank hands it to him and the Cholo lights hi smoke.

Thanks. And he walks back to his junker car, where Hank sees evid of someone else sleeping in the back seat. A small Americ flag flies clipped to the window. Several other vehicles are parked in this REST STOP off t interstate, mostly trucks and campers. Out in the patch of grass a young boy kicks a soccer ball around while his parents sleep.
Dad?.... Dad! Hank smiles to himself, grabs his bag and opens his door.
Hank puts away his shaving kit, buttons the cuffs of his newly pressed cotton shirt.
The pickup drifts up to the guard kiosk and Hank hands th GUARD his ID - RETIRED MILITARY.
Hank waits. SERGEANT FIRST CLASS DAN CARNELLI steps out.
Sgt. Deerfield?
Hank. Thanks for seeing me, I know you're busy. (CONTINUED)
(walking him in) You should have let me know you were coming; I would have cleared some time. Bet the base has changed a lot since your day.
Hank and Sgt. Carnelli sit. A corporal brings in coffee.
What about his buddies?

We asked, of course. (re: coffee) Thanks. (to Hank) A lot of men are just coming back today from a 72. I don't want you to think I'm not concerned, but where these boys have been, it's a miracle more of them don't blow outta here for a few days. For the last eighteen months they couldn't drink, couldn't even flirt with a woman. They touch down, the first thing they do is find a bar and a girl. I expect your son will come stumbling in looking for a shot of penicillin.
...You mind if I had a look at his quarters?
Men come and go in their Green BDUs. Sgt. Carnelli and Ha weave through the men. Carnelli spots CORPORAL STEVE PENN 22, calls to him:
Penning.
Yes, Sergeant.
This is Specialist Deerfield's father. (CONTINUED)
Steve Penning, good to meet you, sir. Have you heard from Mike?
No.
Mr. Deerfield wants to take a look at his son's quarters.
(to Hank) Certainly, sir. Shortcut is through here. (leads them) Mike and I go back to Bosnia, he sure told me enough stories about you. He hasn't called or anything?
You find that surprising?

You'd know better than me, sir, but I recall Mike showing up for roll call with a collarbone sticking through his skin. Penning spots two soldiers ahead watching a foosball game Calls tot Meet SPECI hem:
Long, Ortiez. This is Doc's dad. ALIST ENNIS LONG, 22 and PRIVATE ROBERT ORTIEZ, Mexican American, same age.
Honor to meet you, sir.
Good to meet you.
Doc?
A nickname we gave him, made no sense. (points to door ahead) That's Mike's room there. (CONTINUED)
Carnelli goes ahead and knocks, then reaches for his ring keys. Hank hangs back with Ortiez and Long.
You boys have any idea where Mike could be?
Sorry.
Must be one hell of a woman. Something makes Hank take a beat before responding. For some reason he doesn't like Ortiez.
Yeah.
Good meeting you, sir. Suddenly Mike's door opens from inside, revealing SPECIAL GORDON BONNER, bare-chested. He just stares at them.
Sergeant?
(taken aback) This is Specialist Deerfield's dad, we've come to look at his bunk.
(stepping back) Then you don't need a key. Somebody took a boot to it yesterday. Carnelli checks the cracked door frame as Hank steps in.
You report this to the CQ?
Yes, Sergeant. Sorry, thought you were somebody trying to steal stuff.
Bonner retreats into the adjoining bathroom. Through it, Hank sees a bedroom beyond. (CONTINUED)
Your room?
Yeah. (re: bed near the wall) That's Mike's bunk there. Bonner goes back to his room to finish dressing. Hank loo around Mike's small room: two single beds, small desks, bedside tables and lamps.
(re: second bed) Who is this?
We lost a man. Hank nods. He opens the closet; all his son's clothes are still there. He searches the top shelf, then pulls a duff bag out of the bottom; checks the contents.
That's your duffel, right?
Yes.

Tried to convince him to use the one he was issued, it was like talking to a wall. Hank walks to the small bureau, opens it, sees the very n folded, neatly pressed t-shirts and shirts squared away i the drawer. Hank suddenly stops and looks around the room just now noticing something by its absence.
There are no photographs.
Sorry?
Mike's always taking pictures, emailing them to me. I don't see any photographs. Or a camera.
You saw the door. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
Property theft is a real problem. I guess that hasn't changed since your stint.

No. Hank steps to Mike's bedside table. He fingers open the Bible lying on it. The inside leaf is stamped: Courtesy o Chaplain Services. He pulls open the drawer and notices a battered cell phone hiding amongst the junk.

(re: Bible) Mind if I take this? His mother gave it to him. I left mine at home. As he picks up the Bible with his right hand he smoothly palms the cell phone with his left and slips it into his pocket. He looks to the bathroom door and notices Bonner, looking away, tucking in his shirt. Did he see him palm t cell phone?
I'd like to, but I can't let you remove anything.
I understand. He puts the Bible back on the bedside table.
Hank signs out and walks off toward the exit.
Sergeant Deerfield? Hank turns to see Penning trotting up behind him.
Hank.
Yes, sir. Before he left for Iraq, Mike was seeing a girl: her name was Jennifer Lopez. We teased him about dating J Lo.
You know where I could find her? (CONTINUED)
Sorry. I'll ask around.
Thank you. Hank turns and walks off.
A young SALESPERSON replaces the battery in Mike's phone.
This thing's been around some intense heat.
It's been in Iraq.
That could do it. (tries power, nothing) Sorry, it's dead. But I can give you a new phone with more features with a two year contract.
Hank stands next to the open door of a panel van. Inside GABRIEL, a cell phone technician sits at a bench with a computer and equipment. He plugs the phone in under:
I need any phone numbers in memory. Garbled information comes up on the computer screen.
This is seriously fried. (searching) Address book. You got numbers for Barracks, Burgers, Chicken, Jenn--
Give me that one. The technician points to the screen. Hank points to the guy's cell phone.
May I? (CONTINUED)
Sure. Hank picks it up and dials the number as the technician continues to work. Hank hears:
The number you have dialed is no longer -- Hank snaps it closed.
Anything else?
Mom, Pizza, TD's and Ted.
TD's?
Local joint. Coulda been more but that's all that's left.
Thanks. How much? Hank digs for his wallet. The technician studies the scre
You want the media? This catches Hank off guard - what media?

The phone tech clicks on an icon and a VIDEO CLIP PLAYS. There's electronic drop out and only sporadic sound, but it's Mike's squad -- BONNER, PENNING, LONG, ORTIEZ, drivi on the road to Baghdad, singing a marching song we only h bits of. The camera pans to the windshield, where we see the convo of assault vehicles. Smoldering carcasses and Iraqi tanks trucks and civilian automobiles line their route. Mike pushes the camera out the window and gets a shot of large FLAG mounted on a pole fixed to the High Back Humve flapping in the wind. He pulls the camera back in and the image freezes on a shot of Mike. (CONTINUED)
That your son?
That's Mike.
Sure as hell glad they didn't get me.
That feeling is probably mutual. Any more?
(taps more keys) Yeah, but they're real corrupted. If you want 'em I got a program at home that might be able to pull them off, but it's real slow. Charge you a hundred flat?
(digs out wallet) Can you email them to me?
Sure.
(handing him $100) Where's TD's?

Naked women twirl on poles to unbearably loud RAP MUSIC. The place is jammed with off duty soldiers. The BOUNCER points to the bar. Hank squeezes through the crowd and fi the BARTENDER. He pulls out Mike's photo and shouts to be heard:
I'm looking for my son! The bartender nods towards the crowd: "good luck." Hank steps deeper into the club, scans the faces. He's quickly overwhelmed.
As he leaves, Hank glances over to a small group of men standing between two cars. (CONTINUED)
Three are Hispanic gangbanger types, two are soldiers out uniform that look to be scoring some drugs. The most dangerous-looking gangbanger eyeballs Hank until he reach his pickup.
The sign boasts FREE INTERNET.
Hank checks in.
You need a wake up call?
I've been waking up without an alarm every morning at four a.m. for the past forty years; I think I'll be okay.
You want to make the wake up calls? Hank smiles and heads for his room.

- Hank checks his email. His In Box is empty. - Hank runs his fingers down the crease of his pants and lays them flat between his mattress and box spring. - He polishes his shoes and squares them beside the bed. - He calls his wife. As he speaks, Hank clicks through a folder of photos his son emailed from Iraq, shots of him his buddies.
But why would he leave without telling us?
I'll ask him when I see him.
Joan sits on the edge of the bed; speaks into the phone.
Hank? (CONTINUED)
I'll find him.
...Okay.
Hank hangs up. Hank stops on a photo that seems to troubl him, we don't see it.
Quiet this time of night.

Hank stands at the self-serve color printer as Mike's pho spit out. Most of them are just snaps of him and his budd One of them is different -- Hank picks it up. It's a photo of what might be a BODY LYING ON THE SHOULDE OF A ROAD, taken from a distance. The image is chilling.
You gotta get me out of here, Dad.
Hank wakes in darkness, disoriented. The clock reads 3:58 AM. He switches on the lamp.

- Hank snaps open the curtains. - He pulls his bed sheets so tight you could bounce a coi off them, and folds an impossibly sharp corner. - A maid pushes her cart along the walkway. Through his bedroom window, Hank's computer comes to life. Hank check his email: no new messages. - He pulls a crisp cotton shirt from his overnight bag. - He takes the local phone book from the drawer.
The first rays hit the Imperial Motel sign. Hank steps in the coffee shop next door carrying the phone book.  21.
He leafs through the phone book; several pages of LOPEZes and a large number of Jennifers or initial "J."

Hank at the payphone, the phone book propped on the shelf lots of pen lines scratching off highlighted numbers. CNN coverage of last night's presidential press conference pl on the TV in the background.

Morning, is this Jennifer Lopez? Do you speak English?... (hangs up, tries next) Hello, I'm looking for Jennifer Lopez. (beat) Beverly Hills, thanks very much. Hank hangs up. Considers. Flips through the book until he finds a listing for ARNOLD BICKMAN. He dials.
Hello?
Arnold Bickman?

Looking out through the glass, we see a man who looks lik he'd be an ARNOLD BICKMAN get out of his camper and limp towards the restaurant like a man who needs a new hip. He Hank's age, but looks ten years older. Unlike Hank, Arnol is no longer "fighting trim." Hank waves him over from hi booth. They shake hands heartily.
My God. Hank Deerfield.
What the hell you doing at home?
You just caught us. We're taking off in the camper to visit the grandkids.
I called you at the base -- (CONTINUED)
The base? Christ, Hank, I retired fourteen years ago.
You did not.
Almost fifteen. How the hell are you?
Fine. You want coffee or a piece of pie?
No, I can't. Helen's waiting in the camper.
(looking) That her? She looks as old as you do. Arnold has to laugh.
You are still the meanest man I ever met. So, what did you do, break an axle and call me for a tow?
No, I was hoping you were still at CID; I wanted a friendly face.
Neither of your boys in trouble, I hope.
No.
What was the oldest boy's name, Darren?
David.
That's right, joined the 82nd Airborne, didn't he? (CONTINUED)
Yeah.
Tough sons of bitches. How's he liking it?
He died. On maneuvers at Fort Bragg. Helicopter crash. Ten years ago.
I'm very sorry to hear that, Hank. Very sorry. The young one?
Mike. He's regular Army, like his dad. He's in Iraq, doing real well. (beat ) I'm just doing a favor for a neighbor; her boy got in a little trouble. Anybody we know still there?
No. All gone. How many times did I call you and say we should get together? Helen HONKS THE HORN. Arnold looks.
She keeps you on a schedule.
The kids are expecting us. They slide out of the booth.
They step up to the door, through which we see Arnold's RV.
You sure there's nothing I can do?
It was just good to see your old sad bones.
I'm gonna call you when we get back. (CONTINUED)
That'd be great. (looking at Helen) Your wife, just how old is she? Arnold laughs and walks off. Hank waves.
Hank comes out of a bar, looks around.
Hank sits silhouetted by the motel signs outside his wind as he downloads a video file sent to him by Gabriel, aka "PhoneGuy@Earthlink.Net."
Mike plays to the camera, readies to toss a football toa young, ragged Iraqi kid in a Baghdad street.

(into camera) Historic moment, first time this kid has ever caught a real American football. Here we go. He hands the camera phone to GORDON BONNER. Mike throws t ball. The street kid catches it and he and his buddies ru away.
No, you run this way! This way! (realizes) Hey, that's my ball you little fucker! We can hear GORDON BONNER laughing. Mike grabs for the ph
(pissed but laughing) Gimme that back. And the screen freezes, end of clip. Hank laughs.
Hank enters.
Hank returns a form to JODIE, the civilian worker wearing headset behind the desk. She gives it a quick glance. (CONTINUED)
Hold please. (to Hank) Your son is in the Army.
Yes, ma'am.
(handing it back) Then you need to see the Military Police.
They're pretty busy with the war and everything, so I'm trying to check things out myself.
All you can do is file a missing person's report --
Fine.
-- in which case you'll need to see the Military Police.
How about you let me talk to someone who does more than answer phones?
Hank waits as Detectives come and go. He rises and STEPS INTO THE OFFICE, where he eyes DET. EMILY SANDERS listeni impatiently to a young white woman we will call ANGIE.
I don't think you understand. He loved that dog.
I'm sure he did, ma'am. But the dog bit him.
A dog bites you, what do you do?
I really don't know. (CONTINUED)
Hank tries to get a male detective's attention; gets the brush-off. He and another detective (HODGE and WAYNE) are having too much fun watching Angie deal with her doggie c

You tie it up, you give it away, you might even shoot it, but you sure as hell don't pick it up by the throat, wrestle it into the bathroom and drown it in the tub! You don't think there's something seriously wrong with that?!
Perhaps he thought it was more humane.

More humane?! It's a Doberman! And he's drowning it right in front of our son, and it's biting him, and I'm screaming for him to stop. Does all this sound humane to you?! Hank tries another passing detective, same result.
Did your husband threaten you or your child with violence?
He'd never hurt us, he just needs help.
Then you should ask the VA about counseling.
You don't think I've been there? He won't go, and he's going to hurt himself, I know it!
I would like to do something --
Really? Cause I would say you don't give a crap. (CONTINUED)
(now pissed and nasty) In fact I do, but crimes against dogs are particularly hard to prosecute. Now I have someone waiting.
Fuck you, lady. And she storms out. Hank takes that as his cue to approac and hand Detective Sanders the missing person's form.
That kind of morning, huh?
(glancing at form) You have to take this to the Military Police.

Yeah, but I'm trying to keep my son out of more trouble. Listen, I know you're busy, but all I need you to do is make a call to his bank, see if he's withdrawn any funds or used his credit card in the last week.
Retired cop or just watch a lot of
Military Police, retired.
Then you know that the Army has jurisdiction over its personnel. I'm sorry, I hope you find your son.

Listen, I don't know what you think your job is. If it is anything like mine, it was to roll up the drunks, twiddle my thumbs and not ask too many questions. But my son just spent eighteen months bringing democracy to a shithole and serving his country. He deserves better than this. He drops the form and walks out.  28.
Looking in through the window we see Hank on the phone. H computer screen shows an on-line banking form.
I found his old checkbook.
Is there anything written on it? I need a password.
Through the bedroom window we see Joan at Mike's desk wit his checkbook, cradling the phone.
There's nothing on it.
Are you sure? Hank hears the sound of email arriving. He minimizes the bank webpage to reveal his email account and an email fro PHONEGUY. He downloads the attachment.
Which do you think it is, Hank: I'm blind or I just don't feel like telling you? Silence. Hank would apologize if he could. Joan knows him well enough to understand that, and not require it.
I'm worried, Hank. I'm really worried.
He's a good boy. He'll have a reason.

The image quality is terrible, chunks of video are missin sometimes half the screen is just garbage. But nonetheles we see what Mike saw as his High Back Humvee patrolled th streets of Baghdad in convoy. FLASHES - out the driver's side window, no more friendly faces. People toss jeers, others scurry out of the way. NOW ON SCREEN: The convoy ahead. Spot sheep herded on the side of the road ahead. (CONTINUED)
Bonner, look, there's your family. Bonner presents his middle finger to the camera.
В». Hank? Hank pauses the video.
I'll find him. I'll talk to you tomorrow. And he hangs up and hits play.
Stop screwing around. Bonner slaps the camera out of Mike's hand. It tumbles to the floor and we see Mike askew.
You coulda broke it!
Stuff it up your ass.
Gimme back my goddamn- -
(sees something) Son of a bitch. Mike's head snaps to the windshield:
Fuck!
Don't stop! Don't fucking stop!
What do I do?!

Speed up! Mike stomps on the accelerator and a second later we hear small thud as something hits the grill and then rolls und the vehicle's undercarriage. They drive on in silence. Bonner's hand reaches down and turns off the camera phone (CONTINUED)
The screen goes BLACK. The SILENCE is punctured by the so of a sharp inhale as...
Hank wakes, startled. He must have fallen asleep, but he can't recall. He checks his watch: 7 PM. He sits up.
Sanders returns from an interview. Several detectives hus past her, including Hodge and Wayne. She calls after them
What's going on?

Don't you worry. If it's an animal- related crime we will call you in. She enters the DETECTIVE SQUAD ROOM. It's empty, just a ringing phone. She walks to her desk as DETECTIVE NUGENT comes out of the men's room, zipping his fly and pulling his coat.
What's up?
They found body parts out on Mesa Luna Road. (off her sick feeling) Don't think the parts are actually on the road.
That's comforting, Nugent.
Hank enters. The motel clerk is watching TV; war coverage
Do you have an iron?
People keep stealing them. World's gone crazy.
You have a good hardcover book?  31.

Police vehicles sit on the shoulder, lights flashing. Flashlights sweep the acres of tumbleweed and scrub brush a couple of dozen men search for evidence. Sanders steps to a small clearing, the remains of a fire. Evidence flag mark spots where bones remain. Sanders kneels to inspect charred bone; notes where it was shattered. Behind her, Wayne addresses a uniformed cop.
I need more evidence markers.
You got all that we have.
Straighten out some coat hangers and buy Dixie cups to stick on the end of them. (hands cop a bill) And get a receipt.

(trudging off) Coyotes had a field day with this one; bones are scattered half a mile. Sanders nods and moves off. Approaching headlights get he attention -- a Military Police vehicle pulls up and parks Two officers step out and survey the scene.
Hank washes his cotton shirt in the sink.
Sanders notices something hidden in the brush. Motions fo a CSI Tech to hand her a coat hanger and a Dixie Cup. Pla it next to:
blackened, the fingers and much of the flesh burned away. too.
Sean? The photographer joins her.  32.
Hank stretches the wet shirt flat over the bureau.

Glancing back to the road, Sanders sees her immediate sen Lt. Burke, standing with CHIEF OF POLICE SIMON BUCHWALD, leans on his car. He doesn't look happy to be here. An unmarked CID sedan drifts to a stop and two plain clot Army investigators step out. By his bearing, LT. KIRKLAND is clearly the one in charge. They join the uniformed MPs already on scene, who are standing with Detective Hodge. Sanders has seen this before and knows what is happening. Lt. Kirklander hands a hundred foot tape measure to the M
heads toward the police chief and her lieutenant.

(to Sanders) Anyone else from the office coming? I could swear we have a couple of secretaries who haven't shown up yet. Detective Hodge grins as he returns from his tete-a-tete with the MPs. In the background the two MPs stretch the measuring tape from the center of the road into the field
Tell me good news, Hodge.
Looks as if the victim was killed by that fire site, then his body was chopped up and burned. Animals scattered the parts.
And you're smiling like an idiot because?
The base bought this field from the city two months ago. City property only extends fifty feet from the center line of the road. Don't think it's our body, Chief. (CONTINUED)

Okay. Find your way home. David slowly turns until he can feel the slight breeze on his neck, then starts walking directly toward the house. Hank stays squatted, watching.
Sanders watches, moved.
Hank and David in their seats. Sanders puts the food on t table and joins them.

Okay, men, dig in. Hank closes his eyes, clasps his hands and says grace silently. David watches him closely, closes his eyes and mimics him. Sanders watches. Hank opens his eyes and reac for the platter to serve.
May I?
Please.
Hank scrapes his plate. David fills up the sink to wash t dishes. Sanders steps in.
(to David) No. Out. Go get ready for bed.
I can do it.
Yeah, and you can also get your butt in bed. (to Hank) You want to do me a big favor, read him some of his book? (CONTINUED)
Hank gives her a look which says he'd much rather do dish
As viewed from the kitchen, through the open door. David in bed, Hank sits on the edge, silently reading The Chron
...You're supposed to read it to me.
I can't understand a word of it.
Do you know any stories?
I'm not much of a storyteller.
Then read the book. Hank considers, thinks of something.
You know where your name comes from?
My mother.
Before that. You're named after King David. Your mother never tell you that? (David shakes his head) Yeah, that figures.
listening from the kitchen reacts, but chooses not to interrupt.
There were two armies assembled, the Israelites and the Philistines; they were both on hills, with the Valley of Elah between them. That's a place in Palestine. You know where that is? (CONTINUED)
David shakes his head.
It doesn't matter. Anyway, the Philistines had a champion, a giant named Goliath.
There's a robot named Goliath.

This wasn't him. Anyway, every day for 40 days, Goliath strode out into the field and challenged somebody from the other side to fight him, and nobody would. The strongest and bravest warriors that the king had were all too scared.
Why didn't they just shoot him?

They didn't have guns. (beat) They had arrows, but there are rules to combat. You don't shoot somebody who is challenging you to fight with a sword. So, this kid, not much older than you, he comes delivering bread. And he says to the king, "I'll fight Goliath."
No way.

True story. So, the king dressed David in his own armor, but it was much too big and heavy. So, David takes it off. He looks around and finds five smooth stones, about yay big. He steps into the field, with his slingshot in his hand. And Goliath comes running, yelling, this horrible scream. And David lets fly the stone. And hits him in the forehead. Cracks his skull. And Goliath falls down, dead.
So, he shot him. (CONTINUED)
With a rock, that's not the same thing. You know how he was able to beat him? David shakes his head, enthralled.

First thing David had to fight was his own fear. He beat that, he beat Goliath. Cause when Goliath charged, David just planted his feet, took aim, and waited. You know how much nerve that took? A few more steps and Goliath would have crushed him. And then he threw the rock. That's how you fight monsters. Lure 'em close to you, look 'em in the eye and smack 'em down.
You fight a lot of monsters?
Sure.
В»..You win?
If I didn't, I would have been crushed, right? David sees the logic. Nods.
Okay then. You go to sleep. He turns off the light and leaves, closing the door behin him, casting the room into darkness.
He likes to sleep with that door open.
He'll be okay. Hank continues on into the dining room. Sanders looks at David's bedroom door, expecting her son to call for her t open it. (CONTINUED)
When he doesn't, she goes back into the kitchen and picks the coffee pot. As she's passing through the hall again, she hears his small voice.
Door. She steps to it, eases it open.
Not that much.
Okay. That's something. She eases it almost closed and heads of to
where she pours them both a cup, deciding not to mention bedroom door.
You know that story isn't true.
Of course it's true. It's even in the Koran. She decides not to argue.
Can I read the men's statements?

No. And there's nothing in them that'll help. The last time any of the men saw Mike was Saturday afternoon, before he left base. Hank takes this in, looks out the window, trying to put t all together. After a moment:
You're a good father. You don't have to prove you loved him, I'm sure he knew.
Hank checks his email - no messages. He notices the corne of the bed is slightly untucked. (CONTINUED)
He strips the bed and starts to remake it. His PHONE RING He picks it up.
Hi. You okay?
Yeah, just about to call you.
She looks to the counter, where a parcel sits wrapped in wrinkled brown paper.
A package came from Mike.
(suddenly interested) What kind of package?
I don't know, Hank, a package. He addressed it to himself. I thought I should open it. Pictures of cocaine run through his head.
No.
Why not?
Does it look like it's been opened by customs or the military?
How would I know? No. Why shouldn't I open it?
Just don't. Wait. (an excuse) We'll open it when I get home. (beat) Please. Put it someplace safe.
Okay, Hank. Good night. She hangs up.  71.
Hank watches another video, images of Mike's platoon on p as they come across a burnt bus, the inhabitants just cin
Dad? You there dad? (beat) Something happened, Dad.
Hank wakes and bolts upright, panting, sweating. He check the clock: 8:06, but the room is dark.
He rips open the blackout curtains and is blinded by ligh

Hank ignores his food and sifts through the photos he pri at the copy place: proud warriors striking poses, squad m goofing around. Iraqis -- groups of blurred civilians, sh from the moving High Back Humvee; detainees, lined up fac a wall, hog-tied on the ground, squatting with hands on h Always in groups, the camera never singling out one perso That is, except for the photo of the body on the side of road. Hank stares at it, trying to figure out why it both him.
Hi. Hank looks up to see Evie, the topless waitress. He stare obviously not recognizing her dressed like a regular pers
Evie, from the bar. "Ma'am"?
Oh, hello, sorry. He slips the photo of the body under the stack of others. An awkward moment.
I saw the picture of your son in the newspaper. When you came in, I thought he was just missing. I'm sorry. (CONTINUED)
Thank you. She notices the top 8x10 photo, the posing warriors.
That him?
Yeah.
May I? She swivels the photo to look at it.

Nice eyes. Takes after his father. She looks at the next, and the next. Hank becomes concern that she'll see the photos of the bodies. Evie stops ona photo of Mike and Steve Penning, arms around shoulders.
Him, I remember. Hank looks. Then to her.
I work at another club on weekends. He was there. Would have been Saturday night.
You remember who he was with?
You only remember the ones that tip.
What's the name of the club?
Hank places a photo of Mike and Penning atop something th reads "Pussy's."
They were here. WIDEN to see the club, too early to be busy. The security monitor beside them flashes from one view to another. (CONTINUED)
Both of them? Saturday night.
Them and their buddies. We had to throw them out. (nods to photo) That one was harassing one of the dancers. Real asshole.
(pointing out Penning) This guy?
The other one. You get a lot of assholes in here but he was going for the prize, yelling all kinds of obscenities at the dancers.
I think you have the wrong man.
You want me to ID a guy, and then you tell me I'm wrong. You two related?
What time did they leave?
Christ if I remember, but they weren't happy about it. Two of them started going at each other in the parking lot. Thought I'd have to break it up myself. Hank turns for the door.
Sanders slaps six photos down on the counter beside the monitors. Four of the photos we recognize. The bouncer jabs the photos of Penning, Long and Bonner.
She scoops them up, puts them in the paper bag that passe as her briefcase and slaps a form and a pen onto the bar. (CONTINUED)
Detective Nugent will wait while you write out your statement. Nugent thinks about grumbling. Sanders calls back as she storms out past Hank, who waits by the door.
I want the pen back, Nugent.
Hank steps out after her and she turns on him.
This is not Saigon, this is not 1967, you do not question witnesses.
I figured somebody should.
It must be frustrating for you, being such a damn good investigator surrounded by incompetent fools. Remind me, what is it you do back in Munroe?
I haul gravel.

Now that's a shame. Think of how many crimes would have been solved over the last 30 years if you'd been on the job. (points to front door) When this goes to trial, the defense is going to say you poisoned the well!
It's not going to trial.
--What?
It wasn't them.
I'm sorry?? (CONTINUED)
I don't know why they lied in their statements about not being with him, but they didn't do it.
They were fighting in the parking lot--!
--That was blowing off steam. You haven't been to war, so you wouldn't understand this. But you don't fight beside a man and then do something like that to him.
That's quite the world you live in.
(walking off) Ask them why they lied. There will be a reason. Sanders watches him get into his pickup, stunned by his arrogance.
Sanders fumes as she waits. Traffic goes in and out. The guard hands her back her ID and waves her on.
Sanders and Kirklander sit across from Penning.
So, you were there.
Yeah.
So, why did you lie?
It's complicated.
Why don't you just tell me what happened? (CONTINUED)

It was no big deal. We'd been drinking, and Mike had been acting really weird. Getting really angry. And he's not saying why. But he starts insulting this stripper, I mean, it was dumb, he made some crack, she cracked back and he starts talking trash. So they toss us out. And we're getting in the car and Bonner is all pissed and saying Mike can walk. Mike grabs him, they start going at each other. But it was just the kind of stuff they did all the time -- the whole macho warrior crap. Nobody got hurt. We got in the car, drove around for a while, then went to the chicken shack, across from the base. Mike bought, for getting us kicked out.
What time was that?
I don't know, around one. Then we came back here. Upon hearing this Kirklander stands and leaves the room. This doesn't go unnoticed.
All of you?
.No, just the three of us.
Why did you leave him there?
Specialist Long has replaced Penning.
Why?
That was the question. Kirklander enters with a thin manilla envelope, sits and puts it on the table in front of him face down. Long eyes him and considers before answering. (CONTINUED)
He stares 77.
We were wasted, we had enough, but Mike wanted to find some meth.
He wanted to buy drugs.
Yeah. Like he needed to be more fucked up, pardon my language, ma'am.
And you think that's what happened to him. He went looking for drugs and ran into the wrong people?
Who knows? Mike always had "secrets." Over there he was always sneaking off somewhere, by himself. He didn't really get along well with people.
So, you were thrown out of the strip club at eleven, you show up at the chicken shack at one. What did you do for two hours?
Drove around. Looking for a party or women, like they were going to hold up a sign.
You stop anywhere?
Yes, ma'am.
...Now you want me to guess.
We found a hooker on 10 Mile Road and she blew all four of us.
Do you remember her name? at her, the question being ridiculous.
No, ma'am. (CONTINUED)
So, why didn't you say this when you were questioned?
We realize she addressed that question to Gordon Bonner.
Because we didn't think Mike would want his parents to know.
...You didn't want his father to know he got a blow job?
And was buying drugs. I wouldn't want somebody telling my parents.
So, what was the fight about?
Mike was in some dark mood, I don't know why. Then he started saying nasty things to that stripper.
Like what?
Just stuff I'm not going to repeat. The woman's a stripper, not something on your shoe.
Out in the parking lot, Penning said Mike came at you swinging.
Might have, don't recall. We thought finding him some sort of sex would calm him down. But not Mike.
You didn't like him much, did you? You got in a lot of fights.
There were people I liked better. (CONTINUED)
So, what was different about that night? Was it just that you hada knife?
I want to kill someone, I don't need a knife, ma'am.
So, you never killed anyone with a knife.
Don't believe I said that.
But I guess in Iraq things were different. Someone makes you mad, you could deal with it.
You lost me.
It's a different world. You have power.
You've obviously never been in the Army.

You have weapons, authority; you put men face down in the dirt, step on their backs, kick in their doors. Someone comes running at you, you kill him. You have to, right? Guy could have a bomb or a gun, you kill him first.
You make the call.
Woman walks toward you screaming, won't stop, does she have a bomb? Not a lot of time to think. You react or die. Ever have to stab someone?
If I did it wouldn't be your business. (CONTINUED)
Kirklander switches off the tape recorder.
You're there one day, here the next; somebody comes charging at me, I'd be reaching for a weapon.
(to Sanders) Did you notice the interview was over? (to Bonner) Let's go. Sanders continues as she walks them out into:
Yeah, I'm finished. I'm just glad none of that stuff bothered you. Because, I tell you, I saw my father come home with things he did that he couldn't live with. It pretty much destroyed him.
Your father? What was he in, Panama? You have no idea what we did over there. And we did it for you.
For me??
So, if I were you, I'd just say "thanks," leave it at that and kiss my ass. And he walks off. Kirklander stays with Sanders.
You happy, or do you want to convene a war crimes tribunal? Sanders turns on her heels and storms back into --
-- and gathers up her stuff. (CONTINUED)
I want the clothes they were wearing and I want to take full body photographs for cuts and bruises. She heads for the door.

You can have the clothes. But you may want to glance at this. He hands her the manilla envelope. The way he said it mak her look at it with curiosity. She opens it and slides an 8x10 photo out -- black and white, a frame from a surveil camera posted at the guard gate: Bonner's car, Bonner dri Penning and Long the passengers. The time and date are stamped large, among other information. 1:26 AM. She understands the significance.
Still want them?
(refuses to admit defeat) Yeah.
He clicks on the computer and plays a video clip again -- sporadic images, mostly black. A prisoner on the floor of a humvee. A SCREAM. Mike is saying something we can't make out. Another SCREAM.
Leave him alone! It ends frozen on Ortiez, who stares hatefully at the cam The phone rings, startling him.
Hello?
(phone filter) Mr. Deerfield? My names is Jennifer Lopez. I heard you were looking for me.
Hank waits uneasily at a nurses' station. A moment later nurse steps in from the adjoining ward. (CONTINUED)
Mr. Deerfield?

The nurse leads Hank through the HALL and into a double r where JENNIFER LOPEZ sits sideways on her bed, her back t Hank and the nurse. A MEDICAL TECHNICIAN is helping Ms. Lopez with something we can't see.
Here's your guest.
I'll be two secs. The nurse exits. Hank realizes the technician is fitting Jennifer with a prosthetic arm.
I think it just needs to be tighter. The technician nods and moves off with the arm.
(nods toward the chair) Please, sit. Jennifer throws her leg back onto the bed and Hank sees t her other leg is missing. Hank tries not to look.
You left a message on my Uncle Jay's voicemail. I guess you found out how many Lopezes there are in the phone book.
Yeah.
I read what happened to Mike. I'm really sorry. He was a great guy.
Did you serve together?
No. I'ma reservist. And I don't think you can call what I did "serving." This happened my first day in Iraq. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
We had no doors on our vehicle, driver pulled to the shoulder, IED exploded. Thank God I had my face turned away from it.
Yes.

Mike and I met two years ago, (smiles) --at a bar. I'd had a little too much to drink and Mike saw this guy pawing me and just laid him out. Bam. He took me home in a cab, didn't even try to kiss me good night. (smiles again) After that, we went out all the time, until he left. He was very sweet. (beat ) He called me when he got back.
(now interested) He did.
Yeah, he came to see me that Friday. She lets that hang.
Did he say anything? You know, anything that could help me find out who did this to him?
No. I don't think so.
How did he seem?

...I'm not sure what I should say. I mean, he was a great guy. And I want to remember him...I want you to remember him that way. She pauses. Hank knows not to say anything -- an old investigator's trick. She finally continues. (CONTINUED)
He wasn't.... There was something in him I'd never seen before. I don't think I should be telling you this.
Please.

When he saw me. He laughed. I mean, at first I thought, "great" -- I mean, I am so sick of the sympathetic looks, laughing was sort of refreshing. So I laughed, too. Then he said...not to worry; the parts he was interested in still worked. I didn't know what to say. Hank takes this in. Jennifer tries to undo the damage.

I'm sure it was just...I don't know what it was. (beat) He talked about you a lot, you know. Before he left. He was really worried he'd let you down. What you thought of him was everything. (beat) I'm sorry I said those things. Hank is overwhelmed. He wants to reach out and touch her hand, but She nods. can't.
I want to apologize on his behalf.
You don't have to, I'm sure he didn't mean it.

I appreciate the sacrifice you made for our country. Hank steps INTO THE HALL. His way is blocked by an approaching gurney, another amputee. He takes another route through the ward. He can't help glancing into the rooms, seeing all the young wounded and limbless patients  85.
Hank searches for his pickup in the parking lot, but can' seem to recall where he left it. The camera rises to reve Hank lost in a sea of cars.

Sanders sits studying the files that Kirklander gave her, finding nothing. She looks up and sees Hank sitting quiet in the waiting area. Gone is his earlier arrogance, he appears almost broken. She stands and approaches.
You want to come in? He stands and follows her to her desk, where they sit.
You were right, they couldn't have done it. They were with Mike at the chicken shack at one. She hands him the folded page that Kirklander gave her.

Bonner, Penning and Long arrived back at base twenty minutes later. He looks at the page: a black and white frame from a secu camera at the Ft. Rudd guard gate -- Penning, Long and Bo in a car returning to the base. The time stamp reads 01:2
The field where we found Mike's remains is a half hour away. They couldn't have even driven there in time, never mind anything else.
They left him there alone, at the chicken shack?
...They say Mike wanted to buy drugs.
That's why they lied?
And they say they were with a prostitute earlier, Mike included. (CONTINUED)
She hands 86.
They didn't think I'd seen soldiers using prostitutes? (Sanders shrugs) They have no idea where Mike went when they left him, who he met?
No. (re: files on her desk) I have statements from every other man in his squad....
May I see them? them over, he leafs through them.
If they're to be believed, no one else saw him after dinner time. Nugent approaches with two evidence bags, stuffed full of clothes.
Lab says no traces of blood on the clothes or their belongings.
Did you look at those clothes? One of the shirts still has crease marks where it came off the shelf.

(still reading reports) Clothes are cheap on the base. First thing you do when you get back is toss every stitch you took with you. There are nine men in an infantry squad. Sanders tries to comprehend the apparent non-sequitur.
.+.Yes?
They lost one man in Iraq, there should still be seven statements. There are only six. He hands the files to Nugent. (CONTINUED)
So, one of them is on leave.
The day I arrived the Sergeant told me all his men were back from liberty. A beat, then Sanders pulls out the list Kirklander gave h
(to Nugent) Read the names.
At NUGENT'S DESK, Nugent on the phone.
This is Fred Gainley at the Buxton Sheriff's office. You missing a man? Because I have Robert Ortiez here on a Drunk and Disorderly who says he's one of yours.
Thanks, I'll send someone over to get him.
Nugent hangs up, turns to Sanders and Hank.
He's AWOL.
Check for priors and warrants. And see if he owns a car. Nugent types. ROBERT ORTIEZ' criminal record appears on t screen, his arrest photo has villain written all over it.
Sanders speaks with detective Manny NUNEZ, narcotics and gang division. Hank waits at a distance, listening.
Local boy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

I first arrested Bobby Ortiez when he was fourteen for drug trafficking. He got bail and the witness disappeared. Couple of misdemeanors after that, then a year and a half ago we liked him for drug smuggling. Suddenly he gets patriotic and joins up.
How the hell did they let him in the Army? Detective Nugent enters with a sheet of paper, passing Ha
No felony convictions. And they've been lowering the standards every month since this thing started.
He has a 1999 Chevrolet Malibu registered in his name.
What color?
(checks) Blue. Sanders shares a look with Hank.
Not enough for a warrant.
He's AWOL.
Army can go after him, we can't.
(reading) Four unpaid parking tickets?
Try Judge Osorio. Nugent leaves to do so. (CONTINUED)
(to Nunez) Any idea where he'd go to ground?
(grabbing his jacket) Finding Bobby was never the problem.
Hank waits as they head out with shotguns, pulling on ves Sanders pauses briefly.
Go to your motel. I will call you.
Nunez's unmarked car pulls out of the parking lot, Sander and Nugent right behind them. As they disappear down the street, Hank's pickup pulls out and follows.
Nugent assumes backup position at his vehicle. Sanders ta the side door. She notes Ortiez's blue Chevy in the cover carpark. Nunez and his partner creep up the front steps.
His pickup cruises up in time to see:
-- bang on the front door.
Police Department, open the door! They take the door down with a ram. Nunez rushes past Cho smoking dope, as his partner holds them at gunpoint.
-- is the first to see...
-- bursting out from a trap door and running along the ri toward the attached garage.  90.

head_text.subj: AT THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE

text: Sanders hears feet clattering on the roof, spots Ortiez j as he jumps off into the alley and disappears. Sanders bo for the back yard, clambering over junk and climbing the back fence. Nunez slams open the back door and gives chase.
Hank watches the game unfold, sees Nugent run back to his vehicle, wills him to do the smart thing:
Take the street, take the street -- Nugent wheels into the alley.
Christ. Hank drops the truck into gear and rolls down the street, turning the corner and paralleling the alley.

We can see why catching Ortiez isn't easy -- this kid run and climbs fences like a goat on steroids. He bounds a fe and jumps into a backyard. Sanders scrambles after him, but stays in the alley. Nugent swerves through the twisting dirt alley, swerving right before breaking hard at a dead end. Nunez comes around the corner. Sanders screams that he's "in the yards." Nunez jumps the fence and pursues as... Ortiez leaps from one yard to the next. Nunez tries a fence and misses, slamming back onto his as Sanders keeps running...but she can see Ortiez is getting away.

Hank cruises, scanning the houses and side yards until he glimpses Ortiez. Hank sees where Ortiez is going to cut into the open. He stomps on the accelerator. Ortiez burst out onto the street. Hank catches up to him and swings op his driver's door, slamming Ortiez to the pavement. (CONTINUED)

Hank grabs his metal trucker's flashlight and leaps out b Ortiez can scramble to his feet. Ortiez's knife appears o of nowhere, but Hank catches him with a kick to the gut t puts him back down. Still reeling, Ortiez lunges, but Han catches him square in the jaw with the flashlight. Ortiez hits the pavement and Hank pummels him viciously.

Fucking wetbacks; it's always knives, isn't it? You enjoy cutting him up? Did you? Sanders arrives and tries to pull him off. Reacting instinctively, Hank elbows her in the face, breaking her nose and sending her sprawling. He doesn't even glance ba he just keeps releasing his fury on Ortiez's bloody face. Nunez arrives a heartbeat later, aiming his weapon.
Let him go! Stop! But he doesn't. Nugent runs up and pulls Hank off, rollin him to the ground; Hank struggles with Nugent, trying to back at Ortiez.
Hey! HEY! What the hell are you doing?! Hank comes to his senses and stops struggling. Sanders struggles to her feet, holding her spurting nose.

Hank opens his eyes. He sits cuffed to a wooden bench. He looks down at his hands, cut and swollen. He glances through the open door and sees Ortiez being released from a holding cell, into the custody of two bur MPs. They head for the exit, meaning they're going to hav to pass Hank. Hank tugs on the chain that binds him as th near.

What was it? You wanted him to carry drugs for you and he wouldn't do it? You afraid he was going to tell on you? That it, Chico? That did it. Ortiez jerks to a stop, face to face with Ha leans in close to his ear and whispers: (CONTINUED)
Wouldn't it be funny if the devil looked just like you? The MPs get him moving again. Hank calls after him:
Come back here, you wetback prick, I'll show you what the devil looks like.
(laughs him off) Fuck you, man. Ortiez disappears around the corner with his guards. He turns and sees Sanders approaching, her nose swollen, a b aid over the cut.
I see you cracked him wide open.
Hold out your hands.
I didn't mean to hit you.
That what passes for an apology in your world? (as she uncuffs him) He isn't pressing charges. You're damn lucky I feel pity for you or I'd be doing it myself.
I'm sorry.
Keep it.
Is anyone going to question him?
I questioned him, they questioned him, we searched his house, there is no evidence that he had anything to do with it! Hank doesn't know what to say. Sanders turns on her heel and walks off.  93.
Hank lies awake in his soiled white T-shirt, staring at t ceiling. The sheets are half off the bed. The room is unrecognizably messy.
The alarm clock reads 10:18 AM. Hank wakes to a knock on the door. He opens it to Sanders.
Something's happened.
Sanders and Lt. Kirklander stand over the gurney.
We found him hanging in his room. A morgue technician pulls back the sheet to reveal Gordon Bonner's horribly discolored face, his neck scarred and r
Did he leave a note?
No.
Kirklander opens a small manilla envelope and tips the contents into Hank's hand. It's a watch, circa 1950.
My father gave it to me when I went to Vietnam. I gave it to Mike.
It was in Bonner's pants pocket. The thought strikes Hank as amazing.
...He was carrying it? He didn't leave a note -- he just put it in his pocket and then hung himself?
I'm afraid it's as close as we're going to get to a confession. (CONTINUED)
Confession. Hank exits, disgusted.
Bonner's car; what color is it?
Blue. Why?
Hank follows Sanders to her vehicle.
You don't kill someone for no reason. That watch isn't proof of anything.
You think your son would have given it to him?
It could have been planted on his body!
So, why did he kill himself, Hank?
I don't know! But tell me how he killed Mike! He had an alibi, he was back at the base! When did he do it? Why did he do it?
...I don't know, Hank. I'm sorry. She climbs into her Taurus, exhausted. Hank shakes his he and walks off to his pickup. Sanders' cell phone rings. She answers it.
Yes?
Nugent on the other end of the phone. He doesn't want to have this conversation. (CONTINUED)
...Remember the woman with the dead dog?

Sanders comes around the corner and steps out onto the st of identical mobile homes, lit by flashers from police vehicles. Hastily dressed neighbors stand across the stre from a home that lies at the eye of the storm. As she walks toward it, she notices a muscular man in his late 20s, close cropped hair, sitting cuffed in the back seat of a squad car. Several officers stand by it, smokin and talking. Everyone shows up for a murder. Sanders lifts the crime scene tape and walks through the open front door, which boasts an Army service sticker.

Sanders weaves through the milling officers. Detective wa catches her eye -- it's the first sympathetic look he's e given her. She keeps moving, finding Hodge in the hallway outside th bathroom. There's water all over the bathroom floor. Smal feet poke over the edge of the bathtub. He speaks kindly.

We drained it. Sanders steps forward until she can see Angie, the woman complained about her husband drowning her dog, lying in t tub, her clothes clinging to her. Sanders squats beside the tub for fear of falling. She as the question she doesn't want answered.
Where's the boy?
He wasn't home, thank God. He's at his grandparentsвЂ™.
That's good. She touches Angie's hand.
That's good.  96.
Hank sits on the bare, stained mattress, phone to his ear
Joan sits in the kitchen, staring out the back door. She makes no move to answer the ringing phone.

The room is busy and yet remarkably quiet. Sanders sits a her desk, going through her phone log and losing herself the minutiae of her job.
